title: 106_hr3592
content: Establishment of Joint Committee. The Joint Committee for Review of Administrative Rules is established with 10 members from the Senate and 10 members from the House of Representatives. Vacancies in membership do not affect the Committee's functions, and a Chairman and Vice Chairman are selected at the beginning of each Congress. The chairmanship alternates between the Senate and the House. The Chairman of the Joint Committee for Review of Administrative Rules is selected by Members from the Senate and the House of Representatives, with the chairmanship alternating between the two houses each Congress. The Vice Chairman is chosen from the House other than that of the Chairman. The Joint Committee reviews rules of Federal agencies as provided by chapter 8 of title 5 of the United States Code. Any joint resolution referred to a committee under section 802 of title 5, United States Code, shall be considered by the Joint Committee. Members report recommendations to their respective Houses. The Joint Committee also has authority over employment and compensation of staff. The Joint Committee has the authority to sit at various times, require witnesses and documents, appoint staff, and utilize government resources. Witnesses are requested to appear before the Committee. Witnesses requested to appear before the Joint Committee will be reimbursed for travel and other necessary expenses. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL REVIEW OF AGENCY RULEMAKING. Congressional Review procedures under title 5, United States Code are amended to include the Joint Committee for Review of Administrative Rules in the process. In the Senate, a joint resolution can be referred to the Joint Committee for Review of Administrative Rules for up to 10 session days before further action. The Joint Committee for Review of Administrative Rules can be discharged from considering a joint resolution if it is not reported within 10 session days. Section 804(d) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include the joint committee in the review process. The Act and its amendments will be effective on January 3, 2001, applying to rules issued after that date. The term "rule" is defined as per section 804(3) of title 5, United States Code.
